reviews.review_msg: VERY boring, VERY dry, read both books RELIGIOUSLY but did not receive a good grade, it even dragged my GPA. Would not recommend this course with him.

Dyck is very nice in person but this course is something like Philosophy you either get it or you don't. If you are a fast and excellent writer then you'll do fine. Tests are all written 3 short ans worth 10% each then 2 longer answers worth 30% each. The final paper was %30 on what you learned in the course max 800 words but he varies it each sem.

Extremely difficult, hardest 100 level course ever. His lecture materials are not clear, and you don't even have to attend. The term paper is super challenging because you're require to write something special. If you write something similar to others, both of you would have lower mark!! What is this for?

Dyck is a terrible professor, but a decent guy. It was very boring, his slides were not helpful or useful, I think he expected students to take notes from what he says. Very passionate and knowledgable about his work, but I didn't learn anything in this class. If you were to ask me what anthropology was, I would not have an answer..

This course, BEWARE do not take with Noel because he can kill your spirit. He stopped giving slide points and when he is "lecturing" half the class can't hear him. He may love what he teaches but he makes students hate it. My worst course this semester at this point only the finals can save me. I don't understand one thing and the TAs don't either.

He lectures directly from textbook then adds one or two of his own examples. The TA doesn't know what he wants her to do either. Know the concepts and the names of everyone in the book. He starts off the course with tacky prezi presentations, then the second half of the course he has no visual aid. READ THE TEXT BOOK. Hes a nice guy though.
I thought this class would be interesting and easy but it isn't. Noel is a really hard marker, and he's not a good teacher.

Relied heavily on the textbook including the one he wrote, TA seemed just as confused in what was being taught. Wanted to get a major in anthropology before I took this class. Now after I hate the subject. worst class.

Taught theory basically out of the (exceedingly dull) textbook. In no way attempted to make lectures dynamic. Assignments suffered in quality; while I enjoyed one of the ethnographies, the other was an absolute fight to get through. This course with this prof was not worth my time.

Very boring teaching format. Chose old studies,books,etc. but didn't show their relevance. Made interesting topics boring and unimportant.  Didn't even mention current events relevant to topics discussed. Would NOT recommend taking a class with him. Easy class but not worth the boredom. If you can, take a class with the amazing Ann Travers instead.
Really enjoyed taking this class. The readings were interesting, the TAs were very helpful, and the prof has a great teaching style.

There was a lot of reading in this class, especially ethnographies. We had four 750-word assignments which were fairly easy and the midterm and final were online which was helpful. Attending lecture and tutorial counted toward our participation mark though. Overall it was alright but be prepared for a lot of reading for a first-year course.
Extremely rude and does not make sense when she lectures. Avoid taking this class.

This was taught as a third-year course that specialized in ethnobotany. Avoid this professor if you're looking for a genuine introduction to anthropology. There were also three mandatory textbooks; the most expensive was the least used.

Lunatic who pushes alternative medicine, is very annoying & insecure and uses needlessly complicated language to explain topics that do not need it. Has unreasonable expectations : Your final essay should be 8-10 pages in length", choose a topic by the end of week 1 and begin your research week 2 (you will need time to read a lot of articles)."

I have taken two classes with Natasha (SA101 & SA356W) and she is such a passionate and caring professor. You can clearly see her love of her work through her lectures and stories she shares. The readings are not dense, and fairly short. Natasha always has a smile on her face as she teaches and it is contagious. 10/10

The course material is very interesting but the way the Professor teaches makes it very hard to understand. The lectures are long and very boring and they do not help you understand the course material. I do not recommend taking this class.

I am currently in my 3rd course with Dr. Ferenczi (I've taken SA101, SA301 & SA356W) & she is truly such a wonderful person. SA101 in particular was my least favourite, as large class sizes and all TA marking make you feel really distanced from her as a person, but in SA301 & SA356W she is super involved & personal with your learning. Love her!

This class was honestly one of the hardest ones I've taken. For an introductory class, the reading for the second part of the term was extremely hard and very random. The class is abstract and really confusing. The grading was way too harsh, especially on the weekly discussions. The teacher focused too much on her own research.
I really enjoyed Dr. Ferenczi has great explanatory lectures but is very reading-heavy. Just do the readings and ask the TAs questions and you'll do well.

She's nice enough, but more than once she made a super expensive, not easily accessible textbook mandatory for a few writings and then you're done with it. I've put the most time into this course and it has been my worst academic class. There's always something due, and unless you've had her before it's really hard to know whats expected of you.

Do not take this class! The class is super lecture and reading heavy and attendance is mandatory. Lectures are super long and boring and hard to understand. The content in the second half of the course is so abstract and random. 3 textbooks required, and the one you focus on is so stupid. Proff seems passive aggressive sometimes and marks hard.

Michael is an alright prof. He's really nice but he often goes off topic during lectures which makes them really boring. The final is a take-home assignment where you have to write an essay in two days.
He's a good professor and I loved having him. TAs were a bit difficult on the grading but a few minor adjustments improved the grading as well

Professor Hathaway is very kind; however, Vaughn (one of the 2 TAs) was the star of the show. If you are lucky enough to have Vaughn as a TA, please appreciate his patience, kindness and fair grading. There are many TA's out there like him. Also, the lecture wasn't mandatory, but Hathaway doesn't post slides, so I recommend attending each lecture.
Just okay. Didn't learn much. Prof was not engaged throughout the semester, didn't seem to care much about getting students into anthropology, didn't seem to teach much.
I made valuable memories and learned a lot about anthropology in his awesome class!

He was a nice professor and was clearly very passionate about what he was teaching. However he didn't upload slides at all so you have to go lecture or read the textbook. The class was boring at times but not too difficult

I just didn't learn much in this class. Lectures are often taken up by long videos and class discussions involving many random examples. When a big chunk of lectures are taken up by allowing 5+ people to share their specific experiences for each point, it's not a lot of specific concepts being taught. The concepts were also very abstract at times.

Prof Hathaway was the BEST! The work load was super light, the work was super easy and was the nicest person!! I would recommend this class to everyone. Its an easy A, the prof is awesome and its pretty interesting!!  nicest guy ever!!

Really disappointed I got a B. I felt I did pretty well and I was really into the course, it was just my mid-term mark that I still don't know why I got a bad grade. I probably should have asked, but whatever. Overall, this is an easy course. I sleep during his lectures and stay awake for the films he shows. The tutorials are what matters the most.

Rambly lectures with too many boring discussions, rarely did more than go over the readings. Movies were good at first but got boring. Assignments were ridiculous and the final is essentially a worthless paper. Either discuss textbooks too little or too much. Only bright spot was the midterm. Wouldn't take him again.
Although not mandatory, his lectures are fantastic. Assignments are also genuinely interesting, and exams are fairly easy. Great first year course!

His lectures are great in my opinion, with Power Point presentations, in class discussions and movies at the end, that I find interesting and bring a perspective to the class. He interacts with the students and answers questions readily which is great! Only complaint is I found two-hour tutorials to be really long.
Not the most organized prof, too many movies in class, speeds through powerpoints so it's hard to take notes, and not always clear. Nice guy though with funny stories related to anthropology.

This class was pretty cool, he showed videos and the text book was okay. There was way too much reading though! It was like 80 pages a week which was a lot. I didn't finish the readings any week and did virtually no readings after the midterm and got a B+. Just attend lecture and tutorials and pay attention and you should do okay :)

Dr. Hathaway is interested in his subject material, and is very approachable, but I almost found his lectures to be irrelevant. I feel like I got more out of the tutorials than I did out of lectures (which were half video clips anyway). I wish he spent more time discussing the content of our readings. Go to class to make video notes though!
He is helpful and non-threatening and is interested in students inputs.

Micheal was an awesome prof! He includes films and movies into his lecture. His exams are easy too since he doesn't require you to do all of the questions. He only requires you to answer part of it. I would take his classes again =)

M.Hathaway is one of the best at SFU. His SA 101 class was one of the best electives I've taken. There is only one MT and 3 papers. The TAs are very helpful and nice. He likes to engage his students and get them thinking. The textbooks are very interesting, the movies get you thinking outside the box and his notes are very good. Hez simply AMAZING!

He loves to engage with his students,experienced in his field of study,and he has lots of personal stories to share. Not much note-taking, just a lot of understanding basic, common-sense concepts. If you're looking for a easy mark,take this course! The only downside is the massive amount of textbook reading you have to do. His ponytail is cool too.

Hathaway is a very engaging professor. His lectures are pretty informal, and there are often videos to watch. The textbook is easy to read and supplementary material is engaging. The only downside is that there is so little content during lectures, when it comes to exam time you wonder what to study (and it is all written answers).

Michael is a really cool prof and conducts interesting, thought-provoking lectures. However...the lecture was at 8:30 in the morning, and I hardly attended, yet still got an A. Most of the material covered on the exams is from the textbooks, which are all excellent. Lisa was an incredible TA as well. This class should NOT be 4 credits...

He is a pretty interesting prof as he always gets us to do group discussion and watch videos. There are a lot of readings, but i always do them the last min before the exam and still do good on them. If you have Pepita for TA, your gonna love her!
He is interested in his subject; however, his lectures could have been done in less than an hour. Be prepared for group discussion. If you get Pepita as a TA you are golden.

This is an interesting class and must be  difficult class to teach because 'anthropology' has a lot of facets and you can't really teach that. However Hathaway does a great job using examples to show you what it's all about. A good TA is key and do the readings! But I really enjoyed this class and plan on minoring in Anthro now!

The material was very interesting but his teaching style is not instructive. Most of the time is wasted in pointless group discussion, he rarely spends more than 30 mins lecturing. The course isn't particularly hard, but you only learn something in the first 1.5 hours so the other 1.5 are a waste of time and money.
A truly wonderful class! Micheal really helps explain concepts being discussed. I looked foward to attending. Very interesting. Highly recommended!

I think he's a fairly new prof, and it shows. Lectures were unorganized and uninformative, and often turned into pointless group discussions. They definitely didn't have to be 3 hours long. If interested in anthropology, maybe you'll enjoy the course, but if you just need some b-soc. credits (like me), avoid at all costs.

Michael is a fantastic teacher. He has an obvious passion for anthropology, and he definitely knows his stuff. The midterm will be very easy if you pay attention in lecture/read the books. The final was brutal, but fair. Also, Michael also looks like a stereotypical anthropologist, which makes it all that much more interesting!!

Micheal is a great prof who makes class very interesting by stimulating a lot class disscusion. His notes are all powerpoint and are not posted on the web. Exams are pretty straightforward and fair. As long as you go to lectures you will be fine. Pepita is an awesome TA she really helped make things clear. Overall great course!

Micheal is an awesome prof. who relates his materials and teachings to the real world and helps his students understand better. Lots of information that could get a littel confusing at times but Pepita was an awesome prof who really helped make things clear, you need to be interested in the course material to do well in class. Overall great course!

His class is good. The prof is organized, but he never puts the notes on the web. Movies and readings can be boring sometimes, the materials like the culture stuff are interesting though. TA is helpful, I love Kate! The ethnographic exercises are easy. The mid-term and final are not really hard. The only thing is I dont like reading the ethnography

i would say that he is a BAD prof.. materials and lecture notes are unclear. boring lecture!!!! reading are boring ... the group discussion during lecture is very useless!!! not recommend people to take this course if he is teaching
wasn't very clear. interested in the course though. i would not recommend this course if he is teaching it.

WELL...not very good,the lecture part is really boring,but he is very organized on the course outline and the main topic of the tutorial.The TA were sucks,can't explained clear and even can't remember what the textbook said.MT and final exam is all about your own idea and understanding of the issue,no multiple choice questions,all about writting!

I actually loved this class... I would go even if I was sick that week.... The prof is great and the TA's are too the work wasnt too hard and the prof made it clear to what the major themes were. Majority of the time I wouldnt read the texts and got all the main ideas from the lecture... Take this class with Hathaway!! He's great!

i loved this class; very interesting and kept my attention for 3 hours which is amazing.,awesome TAs, great course. highly suggest this class if you have any interest in it. films in class were very relevant and interesting.HIGHLY RECOMMEND! :)

A very good prof.  Lectures are interesting and include a lot of discussion, and all the TAs were excellent.  Good choices for ethnographic reading and films, but the Delaney course textbook was terribly written.  The interaction encouraged in class is this course's strong point.
No Comments

He's a good teacher and could get boring at times. His midterm and final could be tough if english is your second or third language. Textbooks are overall decent; honestly, some of them could be really boring and repeat and overexaggerate things too much.

Insanely boring. Presence at the lectures twice a week are mandatory, as they are 10% of a grade. Professor didn't deliver the lectures or any valuable information. For some reason he was expecting the students to provide him with the answers on his questions. Kind of reverse teaching. the exams questions were quite tricky.. don't waste your time
I think he is a nice proff, but he relies on the text book too much. Make sure memorize all terminologies for m/c on the exams.

Extremely dull when it comes to teaching: does not expand on the textbook at all (lectures are just a reiteration of what you've already read).  He expects you to know every minute and irrelevant detail however, so be sure to read the textook carefully!  I would advise against this class.
most dryest teacher ever, the topics covered should be interesting but he just sucks it all out.

Excellent professor! I love the way he teaches, and he is so funny. There are no exams or tests in this class. Just be prepared to read and do a reading response every week. Do the extra readings for bonus marks. You get out of it what you put in. I would take another class with Bascom again. I highly recommend his class.

For a class titled "introduction to anthropology", this class seems to prioritize climate change and topics in sustainability instead of the study of people. Mandatory participation and readings included, which are long and unreasonable. Professor also absolutely allows ZERO electronic devices at all under the pretense of anthropology... Comeon....

Bascom is really an amazing prof! He is super caring and teaches material thoroughly. There are no exams but there are reading responses and projects that count significantly towards your grade. He is not an easy marker but if you put in the work and show you care it will pay off. Got to say, one of the best and most memorable classes I have taken.

This is a great prof to have especially for first year! He is easily approachable and paces his course very well because you'll never find yourself stressing out about due dates nor the assignment overall.

I was glad there were no exams before I enrolled this course. Still, there's some reading responses that's due Sun. at noon, and a project that due at the semester. Still, I lliked how he plays some songs at the beginning of the Lec. Overall, you've rocked Bascom

there is weekly reading responses which are easy but take lots of time.
one project that you work on throughout the semester that is very fun.
you can tell he is very passionate about what he does and he makes the classroom environment fun.
attendance to lecture is mandatory.

Professor Bascom is an excellent professor at SFU, truly cares about the wellbeing of his students and is an interesting lecturer. His homework is reading heavy with around 30-50 pages of homework a week, but nothing you can't knock out in a few hours. Climate-Change is important for this class.

Bascom is the most caring prof I've had so far. Although his course was reading heavy, and the lectures weren't as invoking, he tries his best to not give so much work and give breaks. He is very comforting and cracks jokes here and there, and no it's not boomer humour. He is sweet, understanding, and you can tell he's passionate

The class had a heavy environmental focus. Lots of related readings to climate change. If this isnt your thing, DO NOT take this course. Lectures were pretty much useless and the TA made it impossible to get a perfect score through their grading (actually told us it was impossible to achieve an A).

FUNNY TEACHER! Brings positive vibes to the classroom so you actually WANT to attend. Gives readings every week which is not the worst thing in the world I guess but they are LONG (and many) pages. Tutorial attendance is mandatory as it is to your participation mark

Probably one of the best profs ever. No examinations and cared more for your learning experience, his playlists are wonderful as well as his attitude/jokes. Participation will help you and assignments engaged your personal interests and perspectives of the world which is what you think to expect from other profs but he a rare one so enjoy !!
SUPER FUN AND ENJOYABLE CLASS. SURPRISED HE ISN'T A 5 RATED PROF

Bascom is a very caring professor that tries to make 8:30 am lectures more entertaining by incorporating stories into his lectures and provides lots of great feedback in his emails. He really tries to help students understand more and this course consist of weekly readings but no test and just very fun projects.

I love Bascom. He is my favourite professor at SFU. He is passionate and dedicated in his work. He speaks his mind and one of the few teachers who is honest with his class. I have so much respect for him and look up top him. The class was so much fun and very straightforward. Weekly responses and a semester long project. Overall recommend him.

Amazing prof and no tests so thats great. Lots of reading and discussions but the topics are always very interesting. The final project and major papers are also very interesting and can basically be about anything you want. He marks a little hard but I would definitely take a class with him again.
Great prof who allows students to be creative in the classroom. 10/10 recommend

Bascom is a caring and approachable prof. He tends to go off topic, but he does put in effort to make the material interesting. No exams and only 2 papers, which is easy for a 4 credit class! But class has weekly reading responses, and the readings can be long and dense for a first year class.

Reading responses due every week! Workload was average, lectures were extremely boring. Talks about topics of the reading response that was already handed in. Makes funny references though, not a bad class.

Loved this class. The lectures were long but I found them quite interesting. Bascom was also my TA for this class hes great and tutorials are pretty chill with bascom. Try getting bascom as ur TA too. I found he was a pretty fair marker. Assignment every week but its not too heavy. Would recommend this prof

Pretty good lecturer. Bland (but socially relevant) material. The class draws you in with the appeal of no exams, but the weekly reading responses and three papers are draining (and are marked hard). Plays music before class and at break. Swears a lot (I think to try to be hip with the kids). Most of the readings are okay, but the book kinda sucks.

Overall, enthusiastic & caring prof. There are no exams (which is nice); however, there are weekly reading assignments in which you may read anywhere from 3-4 different readings and provide short responses for each one (which as mentioned, can be tedious) Three essays, ranging from 6-8 pages. LEC & TUT attendance/participation are taken (worth 10%)

Overall a manageable and fair class. Weekly reading responses were a bit tedious but not terrible. All the paper topics were very flexible and addressed real-life issues, which was actually useful to learn about. Jeremy was a great TA and a fair marker so get him! If you're a strong writer it'll be easy to score a high mark in this course.

Was kind of frustrated with this prof, the course seemed like it had interesting content but the structure of the course was annoying and I feel like I learned nothing. It seems easy because there are no tests but the essay topics are difficult and the prof is unhelpful about narrowing down what it is he wants you to write.
Hes a great prof and really funny. Class was an easy pass but the readings were heavy and the tutorials were boring (depending on the TA)

he just likes to hear himself talk. there is no tests but there are three papers plus weekly reading summary reports to do. class isnt needed to write the papers but attendance is 10% of the grade and there are no allowed absences. prof is nice but that's the only thing going for this course. not that interesting, was disappointed in this course.
No textbooks. I mean there are but theyre free

Bascom is a really happy and passionate prof that loves to talk. He can sometimes get really caught up in what he's talking about and forget to engage the class. He also loves to ask questions and pick people out to answer.

He's a pretty chill guy, but his lectures were really dry and not very informative. there's no exams but 3 papers that lectures don't help with. the weekly reading responses are slightly tedious but manageable. he really enjoys group discussions. not sure if he'll assign a book in the future as the library has a copy online now

Bascom is a caring prof that discusses anthropology in a very grounded way with many examples. There were 3 papers and no exams, which was nice, but the lectures didn't really help with the papers, and they got a bit boring sometimes because he likes to go on long tangents. Other than that, easy course and good prof.

Bascom is a really fun prof I had him for tutorials as well and he makes class enjoyable even though lectures are 2 hours long plus another 2 for tutorial I never got tired of him the only thing is the weekly readings are time-consuming and also attendance is mandatory but overall i love bascom and i wish he taught my other classes as well

He has almost all the readings online which cuts down txtbook costs. There are weekly reading assignments which can be tedious but it helps maintain your writing skills for the papers. This course is paper based, no tests. Papers are how to apply the concepts. You have 3 papers which are manageable and he makes anthro interesting. Participation 10%

Super fun prof. Really easy to talk to. There are no tests or exams in this class- just 3 papers. Reading responses due every Sunday. Textbook isn't exactly required but is needed for the last 3 reading responses. Would take this class again!

a pretty chill dude, good interesting lectures. good ta  good experience. weekly reading responses are annoying but not toooo difficult. no tests is really great. a lot of understanding ideas, not memorizing specific things. 10/10 would recommend Bascom my boy. best DJ ever.

The lectures were more boring as the weeks went on. The weekly reading responses are a little annoying, but better than a test! That being said he can be a tough marker for papers and the like. Bascom is annoyingly liberal to the point where he gets offended about things that are not even a problem (and that's coming from a liberal myself). Meh.

Bascom was clearly well educated on all of the topics and brought forth great thought evoking ideas as well as encouraged respectful discussion. The weekly reading responses are a little annoying but end up not being worth much, plus no tests! That being said he can be a tough marker for papers and the like. Overall, great prof :)
